hints_html: Try solving for the numerical values of \(y'\) and \(y''\) before plugging them into the formula for curvature.
hints_latex:
Try solving for the numerical values of $y'$ and $y''$ before plugging
them into the formula for curvature.
hints_raw: Try solving for the numerical values of <math>y'</math> and <math>y''</math> before plugging them into the formula for curvature.
question: 4 (c)
sols_html:
It will be complicated to simply plug our expressions for \(y'\) and \(y''\) into the formula for curvature. Instead it might be wiser to calculate the actual value of \(y'\) and \(y''\) at the point \((1,1)\).

For \(y'\) we have

\[\begin{aligned} y' = \frac{-(1)^3}{(1)^3} = -1\end{aligned}\]

And for \(y''\) we have

\[\begin{aligned} y'' = \frac{3(1)^2(-(1) + (1)(-1))}{(1)^4} = -6\end{aligned}\]

Plugging these values of \(y' = -1\) and \(y'' = 6\) into the formula for K we get:

\[\begin{aligned} K = \frac{-6}{(1 + (-1)^2)^{3/2}} = \frac{-6}{2^{3/2}} = \frac{-3}{\sqrt{2}}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
It will be complicated to simply plug our expressions for <math>y'</math> and <math>y''</math> into the formula for curvature.  Instead it might be wiser to calculate the actual value of <math>y'</math> and <math>y''</math> at the point <math>(1,1)</math>.  

For <math>y'</math> we have

:<math> y' = \frac{-(1)^3}{(1)^3} = -1</math>

And for <math>y''</math> we have

: <math>y'' = \frac{3(1)^2(-(1) + (1)(-1))}{(1)^4} = -6</math>

Plugging these values of <math>y' = -1</math> and <math>y' ' = 6</math> into the formula for ''K'' we get:

: <math> K = \frac{-6}{(1 + (-1)^2)^{3/2}} = \frac{-6}{2^{3/2}} = \frac{-3}{\sqrt{2}}</math>.
statement_html:
Given a curve, its curvature K is a measure of how much it deviates from a straight line. It can be computed using the following formula:

\[\begin{aligned} K = \frac{y''}{\left(1+(y')^2\right)^{3/2}}\end{aligned}\]

In this question you will calculate the curvature of the curve x4 + y4 = 2 at a certain point.

Find the curvature K of the curve \(x^4 + y^4 = 2\) at the point (1,1).
statement_raw:
''Given a curve, its '''curvature''' K is a measure of how much it deviates from a straight line. It can be computed using the following formula:''

:<math>
K = \frac{y''}{\left(1+(y')^2\right)^{3/2}}
</math>

''In this question you will calculate the curvature of the curve x<sup>4</sup> + y<sup>4</sup> = 2 at a certain point.''

Find the curvature ''K'' of the curve <math>x^4 + y^4 = 2</math> at the point (1,1).
